Edward O. Wilson was born in Birmingham, Alabama, in 1929. In his early childhood, he became interested in nature and spent much time in the outdoors. At age seven, he was partially blinded in a fishing accident; his reduced sight led Wilson to the study of ants. He could not observe larger animals from a distance. Instead, he concentrated on smaller creatures he could study up close. After studying evolutionary biology at the University of Alabama, Wilson transferred to Harvard University, where he became a professor in 1956. He never received a Nobel Prize ― the prize didn't recognize research in the field of evolutionary biology. However, he was awarded the Crafoord Prize in 1990. Wilson, known to some as the "modern-day Darwin", died at the age of 92 in Massachusetts.

Studies of experts provide insight into what it means to have deep and flexible understanding. Experts in a particular domain are people who have deep, richly interconnected ideas about the world. They are not just good thinkers or people who are exceptionally smart. Rather, experts have knowledge in a specific domain ― such as chess, chemistry, or tennis ― and are not generalists. However, experts do not just know "a bunch of facts." In fact, having expertise in a topic means that knowledge is organized into coherent frameworks, and the expert understands the inter-relationship between facts and can distinguish which ideas are most central. This kind of deep but organized understanding allows for greater flexibility in learning and facilitates application across multiple contexts.

It is natural for people to observe happenings and then seek explanations for why those happenings occurred. But sometimes the reasoning is wrong because of one or more misconceptions. One of these is the ecological fallacy, where an argument claims that there is a causal relationship between two things merely because they occur together. For example, in the 1950s it was found that crime rates were the highest in neighborhoods where immigrants were most numerous. Some people used this "co-occurrence" to argue that immigrants were a cause of crime. But a careful analysis of this situation revealed that immigrants were forced to live in neighborhoods where crime rates were already high; they could not afford more expensive housing in safer neighborhoods. Immigrants themselves committed very few of the crimes. Unless you analyze the claim carefully, you would misinterpret the relationship and thereby construct a faulty belief.

In everyday life, we use previous experience to predict where we should pay attention. Different environments create different expectations. This was profoundly illustrated by the scientist Jared Diamond in his book Guns, Germs, and Steel. He describes an adventure wandering through the New Guinea jungle with native New Guineans. He relates that these natives tend to perform poorly at tasks Westerners have been trained to do since childhood. But they are hardly stupid. They can detect the most subtle changes in the jungle, good for following the tracks of a predator or for finding the way back home. They know which insects to leave alone, know where food exists, can build and tear down shelters with ease. Diamond, who had never spent time in such places, has no ability to pay attention to these things. Were he to be tested on such tasks, he also would perform poorly.

Most entrepreneurs put in tremendous amounts of time and effort in creating and launching new products and services and then make the mistake of overpricing them. They have created something they care deeply about, it's theirs, and this powerful sense of ownership distorts their perception of value which causes them to overprice their products. While many of them are quick to realize that their initial prices are too high, not all these people are happy or willing to drop their prices to make their products more attractive. And this can be a very costly mistake that may lead to the failure of their new business. When you launch a new product or service, your priority should be to get sufficient market adoption as soon as possible and you should be ready to sacrifice your initial prices and profits to achieve this aim. Once you have strong sales volumes, you can increase your prices to maximize your profits.

In most respects, humans are one of a relatively small number of species that evolved a very different strategy of investing more energy to reproduce more slowly. Like apes and elephants, we mature at a leisurely pace, grow large bodies, and have few babies but devote much time and energy to raising them well. This unusual strategy succeeds because while apes and elephants produce fewer babies than mice, a larger percentage of their offspring survive to then reproduce. A house mouse can become a mother when she is just five weeks old, has four to ten pups per litter, and can have a new litter every two months over the course of her approximately twelve-month life. However, the vast majority of her pups die young. In contrast, a chimp or elephant mother does not reproduce until she is at least twelve years old, and she gives birth to only one infant every five or six years over the next thirty or so years. About half of these offspring make it to becoming parents.

When scientists make an important new discovery or experimentally prove some hypothesis, they do not, in general, keep that information to themselves so that they alone can consider its meaning and derive additional theories from it. Instead, they publish their results and make their data available for inspection. This makes it possible for other scientists to reconsider their data and possibly refute their conclusions. More important, though, it makes it possible for other scientists to use that data to construct new hypotheses and perform new experiments. The assumption is that society as a whole will end up knowing more if information is spread as widely as possible, rather than being limited to a few people. In a strict sense, every scientist depends on the work of other scientists.

Most entrepreneurs put in tremendous amounts of time and effort in creating and launching new products and services and then make the mistake of overpricing them. They have created something they care deeply about, it's theirs, and <u>this powerful sense of ownership distorts their perception of value</u> which causes them to overprice their products. While many of them are quick to realize that their initial prices are too high, not all these people are happy or willing to drop their prices to make their products more attractive. And this can be a very costly mistake that may lead to the failure of their new business. When you launch a new product or service, your priority should be to get sufficient market adoption as soon as possible and you should be ready to sacrifice your initial prices and profits to achieve this aim. Once you have strong sales volumes, you can increase your prices to maximize your profits.

annotations.text: 밑줄 친 we mature at a leisurely pace, grow large bodies, and have few babies but devote much time and energy to raising them well가 다음 글에서 의미하는 바로 가장 적절한 것은?

In most respects, humans are one of a relatively small number of species that evolved a very different strategy of investing more energy to reproduce more slowly. Like apes and elephants, <u>we mature at a leisurely pace, grow large bodies, and have few babies but devote much time and energy to raising them well</u>. This unusual strategy succeeds because while apes and elephants produce fewer babies than mice, a larger percentage of their offspring survive to then reproduce. A house mouse can become a mother when she is just five weeks old, has four to ten pups per litter, and can have a new litter every two months over the course of her approximately twelve-month life. However, the vast majority of her pups die young. In contrast, a chimp or elephant mother does not reproduce until she is at least twelve years old, and she gives birth to only one infant every five or six years over the next thirty or so years. About half of these offspring make it to becoming parents.

When scientists make an important new discovery or experimentally prove some hypothesis, they do not, in general, keep that information to themselves so that they alone can consider its meaning and derive additional theories from it. Instead, they publish their results and make their data available for inspection. This makes it possible for other scientists to reconsider their data and possibly refute their conclusions. More important, though, it makes it possible for other scientists to use that data to construct new hypotheses and perform new experiments. The assumption is that society as a whole will end up knowing more if information is spread as widely as possible, rather than being limited to a few people. In a strict sense, <u>every scientist depends on the work of other scientists</u>.

Edward O. Wilson was born in Birmingham, Alabama, in 1929. In his early childhood, he became interested in nature and spent much time in the outdoors. At age seven, he was partially blinded in a fishing accident; his reduced sight led Wilson to the study of ants. He could not observe larger animals from a distance. Instead, he concentrated on smaller creatures he could study up close. After studying evolutionary biology at the University of Alabama, Wilson transferred to Harvard University, where he became a professor in 1956. He never received a Nobel Prize — the prize didn't recognize research in the field of evolutionary biology. However, he was awarded the Crafoord Prize in 1990. Wilson, known to some as the "modern-day Darwin", died at the age of 92 in Massachusetts.

To determine the mass of my bowling ball, I might put it onto a balance and compare it with a known mass, such as a number of metal cubes each weighing 1, 10, or 100 grams. Things get much more complicated if I want to know the mass of a distant star. How do I measure it? We can roughly say that measuring the mass of a star involves various theories. If we want to measure the mass of a binary star, we first determine a center of mass between the two stars, then their distance from that center which we can then use, together with a value for the period and a certain instance of Kepler's Third Law, to calculate the mass. In other words, in order to "measure" the star mass, we measure other quantities and use those values, together with certain equations, to calculate the mass. Measurement is not a simple and unmediated estimation of independently existing properties, but a determination of certain magnitudes before the background of a number of accepted theories.

It is natural for people to observe happenings and then seek explanations for why those happenings occurred. But sometimes the reasoning is wrong because of one or more misconceptions. One of these is the ecological fallacy, where an argument claims that there is a causal relationship between two things merely because they occur together. For example, in the 1950s it was found that crime rates were the highest in neighborhoods where immigrants were most numerous. Some people used this "co-occurrence" to argue that immigrants were a cause of crime. But a careful analysis of this situation revealed that immigrants were forced to live in neighborhoods where crime rates were already high; they could not afford more expensive housing in safer neighborhoods. Immigrants themselves committed very few of the crimes. Unless you analyze the claim carefully, you would misinterpret the relationship and thereby construct a faulty belief.

In everyday life, we use previous experience to predict where we should pay attention. Different environments create different expectations. This was profoundly illustrated by the scientist Jared Diamond in his book Guns, Germs, and Steel. He describes an adventure wandering through the New Guinea jungle with native New Guineans. He relates that these natives tend to perform poorly at tasks Westerners have been trained to do since childhood. But they are hardly stupid. They can detect the most subtle changes in the jungle, good for following the tracks of a predator or for finding the way back home. They know which insects to leave alone, know where food exists, can build and tear down shelters with ease. Diamond, who had never spent time in such places, has no ability to pay attention to these things. Were he to be tested on such tasks, he also would perform poorly.

They are not just good thinkers or people who are exceptionally smart. Rather, experts have knowledge in a specific domain — such as chess, chemistry, or tennis — and are not generalists. However, experts do not just know "a bunch of facts." In fact, having expertise in a topic means that knowledge is organized into coherent frameworks, and the expert understands the inter-relationship between facts and can distinguish which ideas are most central. This kind of deep but organized understanding allows for greater flexibility in learning and facilitates application across multiple contexts.

annotations.text: 다음 글의 주제로 가장 적절한 것은?

It is natural for people to observe happenings and then seek explanations for why those happenings occurred. But sometimes the reasoning is wrong because of one or more misconceptions. One of these is the ecological fallacy, where an argument claims that there is a causal relationship between two things merely because they occur together. For example, in the 1950s it was found that crime rates were the highest in neighborhoods where immigrants were most numerous. Some people used this "co-occurrence" to argue that immigrants were a cause of crime. But a careful analysis of this situation revealed that immigrants were forced to live in neighborhoods where crime rates were already high; they could not afford more expensive housing in safer neighborhoods. Immigrants themselves committed very few of the crimes. Unless you analyze the claim carefully, you would misinterpret the relationship and thereby construct a faulty belief.

① Historical misconceptions about immigration that led to discriminatory policies and practices
② How socioeconomic factors affect housing options for vulnerable populations in urban areas
③ Immigrants' experiences with crime in high-poverty neighborhoods during the mid-twentieth century
④ The ecological fallacy as a reasoning error that mistakes correlation for causation
⑤ Methods for conducting careful analysis to avoid misinterpreting statistical data about crime

In everyday life, we use previous experience to predict where we should pay attention. Different environments create different expectations. This was profoundly illustrated by the scientist Jared Diamond in his book Guns, Germs, and Steel. He describes an adventure wandering through the New Guinea jungle with native New Guineans. He relates that these natives tend to perform poorly at tasks Westerners have been trained to do since childhood. But they are hardly stupid. They can detect the most subtle changes in the jungle, good for following the tracks of a predator or for finding the way back home. They know which insects to leave alone, know where food exists, can build and tear down shelters with ease. Diamond, who had never spent time in such places, has no ability to pay attention to these things. Were he to be tested on such tasks, he also would perform poorly.

annotations.html:

annotations.text: 다음 글의 주제로 가장 적절한 것은?

Most entrepreneurs put in tremendous amounts of time and effort in creating and launching new products and services and then make the mistake of overpricing them. They have created something they care deeply about, it's theirs, and this powerful sense of ownership distorts their perception of value which causes them to overprice their products. While many of them are quick to realize that their initial prices are too high, not all these people are happy or willing to drop their prices to make their products more attractive. And this can be a very costly mistake that may lead to the failure of their new business. When you launch a new product or service, your priority should be to get sufficient market adoption as soon as possible and you should be ready to sacrifice your initial prices and profits to achieve this aim. Once you have strong sales volumes, you can increase your prices to maximize your profits.

annotations.html:
① The emotional attachment entrepreneurs develop toward their products and its consequences
② Why entrepreneurs are reluctant to lower prices despite recognizing their products are overpriced
③ The importance of strategic pricing for market adoption before pursuing higher profits
④ How entrepreneurs can maximize profits by adjusting prices after achieving market adoption
⑤ Common pricing mistakes made by entrepreneurs when launching new products or services

① The emotional attachment entrepreneurs develop toward their products and its consequences
② Why entrepreneurs are reluctant to lower prices despite recognizing their products are overpriced
③ The importance of strategic pricing for market adoption before pursuing higher profits
④ How entrepreneurs can maximize profits by adjusting prices after achieving market adoption
⑤ Common pricing mistakes made by entrepreneurs when launching new products or services

annotations.html: 다음 글의 주제로 가장 적절한 것은?
annotations.text: 다음 글의 주제로 가장 적절한 것은?

In most respects, humans are one of a relatively small number of species that evolved a very different strategy of investing more energy to reproduce more slowly. Like apes and elephants, we mature at a leisurely pace, grow large bodies, and have few babies but devote much time and energy to raising them well. This unusual strategy succeeds because while apes and elephants produce fewer babies than mice, a larger percentage of their offspring survive to then reproduce. A house mouse can become a mother when she is just five weeks old, has four to ten pups per litter, and can have a new litter every two months over the course of her approximately twelve-month life. However, the vast majority of her pups die young. In contrast, a chimp or elephant mother does not reproduce until she is at least twelve years old, and she gives birth to only one infant every five or six years over the next thirty or so years. About half of these offspring make it to becoming parents.

annotations.html:
① The evolutionary advantage of humans' slow reproductive strategy compared to other species
② How different animal species balance quantity versus quality in their offspring production
③ The contrast between fast-breeding small mammals and the parental investment of larger species
④ The relationship between reproductive age and survival rates across mammalian species
⑤ The surprising similarities between human and mouse reproductive cycles and strategies

⑤ The surprising similarities between human and mouse reproductive cycles and strategies

When scientists make an important new discovery or experimentally prove some hypothesis, they do not, in general, keep that information to themselves so that they alone can consider its meaning and derive additional theories from it. Instead, they publish their results and make their data available for inspection. This makes it possible for other scientists to reconsider their data and possibly refute their conclusions. More important, though, it makes it possible for other scientists to use that data to construct new hypotheses and perform new experiments. The assumption is that society as a whole will end up knowing more if information is spread as widely as possible, rather than being limited to a few people. In a strict sense, every scientist depends on the work of other scientists.

annotations.html:
① How scientific experiments are designed to test hypotheses and generate reliable data
② The critical role of peer review in validating scientific discoveries and experimental results
③ The competitive nature of scientific research and its impact on information disclosure
④ The challenges scientists face when attempting to publish groundbreaking research findings
⑤ The importance of sharing scientific discoveries for collective knowledge advancement and progress

⑤ The importance of sharing scientific discoveries for collective knowledge advancement and progress

Edward O. Wilson was born in Birmingham, Alabama, in 1929. In his early childhood, he became interested in nature and spent much time in the outdoors. At age seven, he was partially blinded in a fishing accident; his reduced sight led Wilson to the study of ants. He could not observe larger animals from a distance. Instead, he concentrated on smaller creatures he could study up close. After studying evolutionary biology at the University of Alabama, Wilson transferred to Harvard University, where he became a professor in 1956. He never received a Nobel Prize — the prize didn't recognize research in the field of evolutionary biology. However, he was awarded the Crafoord Prize in 1990. Wilson, known to some as the "modern-day Darwin", died at the age of 92 in Massachusetts.

④ Nobel Prize Limitations in Recognizing Scientific Achievement

Edward O. Wilson was born in Birmingham, Alabama, in 1929. In his early childhood, he became interested in nature and spent much time in the outdoors. At age seven, he was partially blinded in a fishing accident; his reduced sight led Wilson to the study of ants. He could not observe larger animals from a distance. Instead, he concentrated on smaller creatures he could study up close. After studying __________ at the University of Alabama, Wilson transferred to Harvard University, where he became a professor in 1956. He never received a Nobel Prize — the prize didn't recognize research in the field of evolutionary biology. However, he was awarded the Crafoord Prize in 1990. Wilson, known to some as the "modern-day Darwin", died at the age of 92 in Massachusetts.

They are not just good thinkers or people who are exceptionally smart. Rather, experts have knowledge in a specific domain — such as chess, chemistry, or tennis — and are not generalists. However, experts do not just know "a bunch of facts." In fact, having __________ in a topic means that knowledge is organized into coherent frameworks, and the expert understands the inter-relationship between facts and can distinguish which ideas are most central. This kind of deep but organized understanding allows for greater flexibility in learning and facilitates application across multiple contexts.

It is natural for people to observe happenings and then seek explanations for why those happenings occurred. But sometimes the reasoning is wrong because of one or more misconceptions. One of these is the ecological fallacy, where an argument claims that there is a causal __________ between two things merely because they occur together. For example, in the 1950s it was found that crime rates were the highest in neighborhoods where immigrants were most numerous. Some people used this "cooccurrence" to argue that immigrants were a cause of crime. But a careful analysis of this situation revealed that immigrants were forced to live in neighborhoods where crime rates were already high; they could not afford more expensive housing in safer neighborhoods. Immigrants themselves committed very few of the crimes. Unless you analyze the claim carefully, you would misinterpret the relationship and thereby construct a faulty belief.

He relates that these natives tend to perform poorly at tasks Westerners have been trained to do since childhood. But they are hardly stupid. They can detect the most subtle __________ in the jungle, good for following the tracks of a predator or for finding the way back home. They know which insects to leave alone, know where food exists, can build and tear down shelters with ease. Diamond, who had never spent time in such places, has no ability to pay attention to these things. Were he to be tested on such tasks, he also would perform poorly.

In most respects, humans are one of a relatively small number of species that evolved a very different strategy of investing more energy to reproduce more slowly. Like apes and elephants, we mature at a leisurely pace, grow large bodies, and have few babies but devote much time and energy to raising them well. This unusual __________ succeeds because while apes and elephants produce fewer babies than mice, a larger percentage of their offspring survive to then reproduce. A house mouse can become a mother when she is just five weeks old, has four to ten pups per litter, and can have a new litter every two months over the course of her approximately twelve-month life. However, the vast majority of her pups die young. In contrast, a chimp or elephant mother does not reproduce until she is at least twelve years old, and she gives birth to only one infant every five or six years over the next thirty or so years. About half of these offspring make it to becoming parents.

annotations.html: In most respects, humans are one of a relatively small number of species that evolved a very different strategy of investing more energy to reproduce more slowly. It is natural for people to observe happenings and then seek explanations for why those happenings occurred. But sometimes the reasoning is wrong because of one or more misconceptions. One of these is the ecological fallacy, where an argument claims that there is a causal relationship between two things merely because they occur together. For example, in the 1950s it was found that crime rates were the highest in neighborhoods where immigrants were most numerous. Some people used this "co-occurrence" to argue that immigrants were a cause of crime. But a careful analysis of this situation revealed that immigrants were forced to live in neighborhoods where crime rates were already high; they could not afford more expensive housing in safer neighborhoods. Immigrants themselves committed very few of the crimes. Unless you analyze the claim carefully, you would misinterpret the relationship and thereby construct a faulty belief.

annotations.html: The ecological fallacy involves incorrectly assuming (A)__________ relationships based on mere (B)__________ of events, as illustrated by the misconception about immigrants and crime rates.

In everyday life, we use previous experience to predict where we should pay attention. Different environments create different expectations. This was profoundly illustrated by the scientist Jared Diamond in his book Guns, Germs, and Steel. He describes an adventure wandering through the New Guinea jungle with native New Guineans. He relates that these natives tend to perform poorly at tasks Westerners have been trained to do since childhood. But they are hardly stupid. They can detect the most subtle changes in the jungle, good for following the tracks of a predator or for finding the way back home. They know which insects to leave alone, know where food exists, can build and tear down shelters with ease. Diamond, who had never spent time in such places, has no ability to pay attention to these things. Were he to be tested on such tasks, he also would perform poorly.

Most entrepreneurs put in tremendous amounts of time and effort in creating and launching new products and services and then make the mistake of overpricing them. They have created something they care deeply about, it's theirs, and this powerful sense of ownership distorts their perception of value which causes them to overprice their products. While many of them are quick to realize that their initial prices are too high, not all these people are happy or willing to drop their prices to make their products more attractive. And this can be a very costly mistake that may lead to the failure of their new business. When you launch a new product or service, your priority should be to get sufficient market adoption as soon as possible and you should be ready to sacrifice your initial prices and profits to achieve this aim. Once you have strong sales volumes, you can increase your prices to maximize your profits.

annotations.html: Entrepreneurs should avoid the common (A)__________ of overpricing new products due to emotional (B)__________, and instead focus on market adoption before raising prices.

In most respects, humans are one of a relatively small number of species that evolved a very different strategy of investing more energy to reproduce more slowly. Like apes and elephants, we mature at a leisurely pace, grow large bodies, and have few babies but devote much time and energy to raising them well. This unusual strategy succeeds because while apes and elephants produce fewer babies than mice, a larger percentage of their offspring survive to then reproduce. A house mouse can become a mother when she is just five weeks old, has four to ten pups per litter, and can have a new litter every two months over the course of her approximately twelve-month life. However, the vast majority of her pups die young. In contrast, a chimp or elephant mother does not reproduce until she is at least twelve years old, and she gives birth to only one infant every five or six years over the next thirty or so years. About half of these offspring make it to becoming parents.

annotations.html: Humans, apes, and elephants employ a reproductive strategy focused on slower (A)__________ and higher parental (B)__________, resulting in better offspring survival rates compared to species like mice.

When scientists make an important new discovery or experimentally prove some hypothesis, they do not, in general, keep that information to themselves so that they alone can consider its meaning and derive additional theories from it. Instead, they publish their results and make their data available for inspection. This makes it possible for other scientists to reconsider their data and possibly refute their conclusions. More important, though, it makes it possible for other scientists to use that data to construct new hypotheses and perform new experiments. The assumption is that society as a whole will end up knowing more if information is spread as widely as possible, rather than being limited to a few people. In a strict sense, every scientist depends on the work of other scientists.

annotations.html: Scientific (A)__________ promotes collective knowledge advancement through information (B)__________ enabling scientists to build upon each other's work.

Edward O. Wilson was born in Birmingham, Alabama, in 1929. In his early childhood, he became interested in nature and spent much time in the outdoors. At age seven, he was partially blinded in a fishing accident; his reduced sight led Wilson to the study of ants. He could not observe larger animals from a distance. Instead, he concentrated on smaller creatures he could study up close. After studying evolutionary biology at the University of Alabama, Wilson transferred to Harvard University, where he became a professor in 1956. He never received a Nobel Prize — the prize didn't recognize research in the field of evolutionary biology. However, he was awarded the Crafoord Prize in 1990. Wilson, known to some as the "modern-day Darwin", died at the age of 92 in Massachusetts.

Studies of experts provide insight into what it means to have deep and flexible understanding. Experts in a particular domain are people who have deep, richly interconnected ideas about the world. They are not just good thinkers or people who are exceptionally smart. Rather, experts have knowledge in a specific domain — such as chess, chemistry, or tennis — and are not generalists. However, experts do not just know "a bunch of facts." In fact, having expertise in a topic means that knowledge is organized into coherent frameworks, and the expert understands the inter-relationship between facts and can distinguish which ideas are most central. This kind of deep but organized understanding allows for greater flexibility in learning and facilitates application across multiple contexts.

annotations.html:
(1) Experts are primarily generalists with broad knowledge across many fields. ( T / F )
(2) Having expertise means organizing knowledge into coherent frameworks rather than just knowing many facts. ( T / F )
(3) Experts are simply people who are exceptionally intelligent or good thinkers. ( T / F )
(4) Deep and organized understanding enables experts to apply their knowledge flexibly across different contexts. ( T / F )
(5) Experts cannot distinguish which ideas are most central in their domain of expertise. ( T / F )

Most entrepreneurs put in tremendous amounts of time and effort in creating and launching new products and services and then make the mistake of overpricing them. They have created something they care deeply about, it's theirs, and this powerful sense of ownership distorts their perception of value which causes them to overprice their products. While many of them are quick to realize that their initial prices are too high, not all these people are happy or willing to drop their prices to make their products more attractive. And this can be a very costly mistake that may lead to the failure of their new business. When you launch a new product or service, your priority should be to get sufficient market adoption as soon as possible and you should be ready to sacrifice your initial prices and profits to achieve this aim. Once you have strong sales volumes, you can increase your prices to maximize your profits.

④ Unwillingness to lower prices can potentially lead to business failure.
⑤ Entrepreneurs tend to overprice their products due to their emotional attachment.

However, the vast majority of her pups die young. In contrast, a chimp or elephant mother does not reproduce until she is at least twelve years old, and she gives birth to only one infant every five or six years over the next thirty or so years. About half of these offspring make it to becoming parents.

When scientists make an important new discovery or experimentally prove some hypothesis, they do not, in general, keep that information to themselves so that they alone can consider its meaning and derive additional theories from it. Instead, they publish their results and make their data available for inspection. This makes it possible for other scientists to reconsider their data and possibly refute their conclusions. More important, though, it makes it possible for other scientists to use that data to construct new hypotheses and perform new experiments. The assumption is that society as a whole will end up knowing more if information is spread as widely as possible, rather than being limited to a few people. In a strict sense, every scientist depends on the work of other scientists.

Edward O. Wilson was born in Birmingham, Alabama, in 1929. In his early childhood, he became interested in nature and spent much time in the outdoors. At age seven, he was partially blinded in a fishing accident; his reduced sight led Wilson to the study of ants. He could not observe larger animals from a distance. Instead, he concentrated on smaller creatures he could study up close. After studying evolutionary biology at the University of Alabama, Wilson transferred to Harvard University, where he became a professor in 1956. He never received a Nobel Prize — the prize didn't recognize research in the field of evolutionary biology. However, he was awarded the Crafoord Prize in 1990. Wilson, known to some as the "modern-day Darwin", died at the age of 92 in Massachusetts.

① Wilson became a professor at the University of Alabama after completing his studies there.
② Wilson received the Nobel Prize for his research in evolutionary biology in 1990.
③ Wilson was born in Massachusetts where he later died at the age of 92.

⑤ Wilson's interest in ants developed after he suffered partial blindness in a childhood accident.

Studies of experts provide insight into what it means to have deep and flexible understanding. Experts in a particular domain are people who have deep, richly interconnected ideas about the world. They are not just good thinkers or people who are exceptionally smart. Rather, experts have knowledge in a specific domain — such as chess, chemistry, or tennis — and are not generalists. However, experts do not just know "a bunch of facts." In fact, having expertise in a topic means that knowledge is organized into coherent frameworks, and the expert understands the inter-relationship between facts and can distinguish which ideas are most central. This kind of deep but organized understanding allows for greater flexibility in learning and facilitates application across multiple contexts.

① Experts are generally smarter than average people in all domains of knowledge.
② The flexibility in learning that experts possess prevents them from applying knowledge in different contexts.
③ Expertise is primarily defined by knowing a large number of isolated facts.
④ Experts organize their knowledge into coherent frameworks that show relationships between facts.
⑤ Experts are good at generalizing their knowledge across many unrelated fields.

It is natural for people to observe happenings and then seek explanations for why those happenings occurred. But sometimes the reasoning is wrong because of one or more misconceptions. One of these is the ecological fallacy, where an argument claims that there is a causal relationship between two things merely because they occur together. For example, in the 1950s it was found that crime rates were the highest in neighborhoods where immigrants were most numerous. Some people used this "co-occurrence" to argue that immigrants were a cause of crime. But a careful analysis of this situation revealed that immigrants were forced to live in neighborhoods where crime rates were already high; they could not afford more expensive housing in safer neighborhoods. Immigrants themselves committed very few of the crimes. Unless you analyze the claim carefully, you would misinterpret the relationship and thereby construct a faulty belief.

annotations.html:
① People who committed crimes in the 1950s specifically targeted immigrant neighborhoods.
② The text suggests that most misconceptions in reasoning are due to the ecological fallacy.
③ A careful analysis showed that immigrants were responsible for very few crimes in their neighborhoods.
④ In the 1950 s, immigrants deliberately chose to live in high-crime neighborhoods to save money.
⑤ The ecological fallacy is a misconception that claims two events cannot occur together without a causal relationship.
annotations.text:
① People who committed crimes in the 1950s specifically targeted immigrant neighborhoods.
② The text suggests that most misconceptions in reasoning are due to the ecological fallacy.
③ A careful analysis showed that immigrants were responsible for very few crimes in their neighborhoods.
④ In the 1950 s, immigrants deliberately chose to live in high-crime neighborhoods to save money.
⑤ The ecological fallacy is a misconception that claims two events cannot occur together without a causal relationship.

In everyday life, we use previous experience to predict where we should pay attention. Different environments create different expectations. This was profoundly illustrated by the scientist Jared Diamond in his book Guns, Germs, and Steel. He describes an adventure wandering through the New Guinea jungle with native New Guineans. He relates that these natives tend to perform poorly at tasks Westerners have been trained to do since childhood. But they are hardly stupid. They can detect the most subtle changes in the jungle, good for following the tracks of a predator or for finding the way back home. They know which insects to leave alone, know where food exists, can build and tear down shelters with ease. Diamond, who had never spent time in such places, has no ability to pay attention to these things. Were he to be tested on such tasks, he also would perform poorly.

② Jared Diamond wrote a book about how to survive in the New Guinea jungle.
③ Native New Guineans perform better than Westerners in all types of tasks.
④ The natives taught Diamond how to build shelters during his adventure in the jungle.
⑤ Native New Guineans can identify small changes in their environment that help them track predators.

Wilson, known to some as the "modern-day Darwin", died at the age of 92 in Massachusetts.

However, experts do not just know "a bunch of facts." In fact, having expertise in a topic means that knowledge is organized into coherent frameworks, and the expert understands the inter-relationship between facts and can distinguish __________. This kind of deep but organized understanding allows for greater flexibility in learning and facilitates application across multiple contexts

It is natural for people to observe happenings and then seek explanations for why those happenings occurred. But sometimes the reasoning is wrong because of one or more misconceptions. One of these is the ecological fallacy, where an argument claims that there is a causal relationship between two things merely because they occur together. For example, in the 1950s it was found that crime rates were the highest in neighborhoods where immigrants were most numerous. Some people used this "co-occurrence" to argue that immigrants were a cause of crime. But a careful analysis of this situation revealed that immigrants were forced to live in neighborhoods __________; they could not afford more expensive housing in safer neighborhoods. Immigrants themselves committed very few of the crimes. Unless you analyze the claim carefully, you would misinterpret the relationship and thereby construct a faulty belief.

He relates that these natives tend to perform poorly at tasks __________. But they are hardly stupid. They can detect the most subtle changes in the jungle, good for following the tracks of a predator or for finding the way back home. They know which insects to leave alone, know where food exists, can build and tear down shelters with ease. Diamond, who had never spent time in such places, has no ability to pay attention to these things. Were he to be tested on such tasks, he also would perform poorly

When you launch a new product or service, your priority should be to get sufficient market adoption as soon as possible and you should be ready to sacrifice your initial prices and profits to achieve this aim. Like apes and elephants, we mature at a leisurely pace, grow large bodies, and have few babies but devote much time and energy to raising them well. This unusual strategy succeeds because while apes and elephants produce fewer babies __________ to then reproduce. A house mouse can become a mother when she is just five weeks old, has four to ten pups per litter, and can have a new litter every two months over the course of her approximately twelve-month life. However, the vast majority of her pups die young. In contrast, a chimp or elephant mother does not reproduce until she is at least twelve years old, and she gives birth to only one infant every five or six years over the next thirty or so years. About half of these offspring make it to becoming parents

When scientists make an important new discovery or experimentally prove some hypothesis, they do not, in general, keep that information to themselves so that they alone can consider its meaning and derive additional theories from it. Instead, they publish their results and make their data available for inspection. This makes it possible for other scientists to reconsider their data and possibly refute their conclusions. More important, though, it makes it possible for other scientists to use that data to construct new hypotheses and perform new experiments. The assumption is that society as a whole will end up knowing more __________ rather than being limited to a few people. In a strict sense, every scientist depends on the work of other scientists

annotations.html: 해설: 본문에 따르면 Wilson은 7세 때 낚시 사고로 부분적으로 시력을 잃었고, 이로 인해 멀리 있는 큰 동물들을 관찰할 수 없게 되어 가까이에서 연구할 수 있는 작은 생물, 특히 개미 연구에 집중하게 되었다. 이러한 시력 손상이 그의 연구 방향을 결정짓는 중요한 계기가 되었으며, 이후 하버드 대학교 교수가 되고 진화생물학 분야에서 "현대의 다윈"이라 불릴 만큼 중요한 업적을 이루는 기반이 되었다.

annotations.html: 해설: 이 글은 전문가의 특성에 대해 설명하면서 전문가가 단순히 많은 사실을 아는 것이 아니라 지식을 일관된 체계로 조직화하고 사실 간의 상호 관계를 이해하며 핵심 아이디어를 구별할 수 있다고 말한다. 특히 마지막 문장에서 이러한 깊고 조직화된 이해가 학습에서 더 큰 유연성을 가능하게 하고 다양한 상황에서의 적용을 촉진한다고 직접적으로 언급하고 있다.

annotations.html: 해설: 이 글은 생태학적 오류(ecological fallacy)를 설명하며, 두 현상이 단순히 함께 발생한다고 해서 인과관계가 있다고 주장하는 것은 잘못된 추론이라고 지적한다. 1950년대 이민자가 많은 지역에서 범죄율이 높았던 사례를 들어, 이것이 이민자들이 범죄의 원인이라는 잘못된 결론으로 이어졌음을 보여주며, 실제로는 이민자들이 이미 범죄율이 높은 지역에 살 수밖에 없었던 상황적 요인이 있었음을 설명하고 있다.

annotations.html: 해설: 이 글은 사람들이 자신의 환경과 경험에 따라 주의를 기울이는 대상이 달라진다는 점을 설명한다. 뉴기니 원주민들은 서구인들이 잘하는 과제에서는 성과가 좋지 않지만, 정글에서의 미묘한 변화를 감지하고 포식자의 흔적을 따르는 등 자신들의 환경에 맞는 기술에는 뛰어난 반면, 다이아몬드와 같은 서구인은 그런 환경에서 필요한 것들에 주의를 기울이는 능력이 부족하다는 사례를 통해 환경에 따른 주의력의 차이를 보여준다.

annotations.html: 해설: 글의 핵심 주장은 신제품 출시 시 시장 점유율 확보를 위해 초기 가격과 이익을 희생할 준비가 되어 있어야 한다는 것이다. 필자는 많은 기업가들이 자신의 제품에 대한 강한 소유감으로 가치 인식이 왜곡되어 가격을 높게 책정하는 실수를 범한다고 지적하면서, 신제품 출시 시 우선순위는 가능한 빨리 충분한 시장 채택을 얻는 것이며 이를 위해 초기 가격과 이익을 희생할 준비가 되어 있어야 한다고 명시적으로 주장한다.

annotations.html: 해설: 이 글은 인간이 쥐와 같은 종과 달리 침팬지나 코끼리처럼 천천히 성숙하고, 큰 몸집을 가지며, 적은 수의 자손을 낳지만 그들을 잘 키우는 데 많은 시간과 에너지를 투자하는 번식 전략을 택했다고 설명한다. 이러한 특이한 전략은 적은 수의 자손을 낳더라도 더 높은 비율의 자손이 생존하여 번식에 성공하기 때문에 효과적이라는 점을 강조하고 있다.

annotations.html: 해설: 이 구절은 Wilson이 어린 시절 낚시 사고로 시력이 부분적으로 손상된 후 연구 방향을 전환한 것을 의미한다. 본문에 따르면 그는 시력 제한으로 인해 멀리 있는 큰 동물들을 관찰할 수 없었기 때문에 가까이에서 볼 수 있는 작은 생물, 특히 개미에 집중하게 되었다. 이는 그의 신체적 제약이 오히려 그를 개미 연구의 권위자로 이끌었음을 보여준다. 따라서 Wilson이 멸종 위기종 연구에 헌신했다는 것이 아니라, 시력 손상으로 인해 가까이에서 관찰할 수 있는 작은 생물에 집중했다는 의미이다.

annotations.html: 해설: 이 구절은 전문가들이 단순히 사실들의 집합만 알고 있는 것이 아니라는 의미이다. 본문에서는 이어서 "having expertise in a topic means that knowledge is organized into coherent frameworks, and the expert understands the inter­relationship between facts"라고 설명하며 전문가의 지식은 일관된 체계로 조직되어 있고 사실들 간의 상호관계를 이해한다고 명시하고 있다. 따라서 전문가들은 단순히 개별 사실들을 아는 것이 아니라 지식을 상호 연결된 일관된 체계로 조직한다는 의미이다.

annotations.html: 해설: 생태학적 오류(ecological fallacy)는 본문에서 "an argument claims that there is a causal relationship between two things merely because they occur together"라고 정의되어 있다. 이는 두 현상이 단순히 함께 발생한다는 이유만으로 인과관계가 있다고 주장하는 논리적 오류를 의미한다. 본문의 예시에서는 1950년대에 이민자가 많은 지역에서 범죄율이 높다는 사실을 바탕으로 이민자가 범죄의 원인이라고 잘못 결론짓는 상황을 설명하고 있다. 실제로는 이민자들이 이미 범죄율이 높은 지역에 살 수밖에 없었던 경제적 상황이 원인이었으며, 두 현상 간의 단순한 상관관계를 인과관계로 오해한 사례이다.

annotations.html: 해설: 밑줄 친 표현은 뉴기니 원주민들이 서구인들이 어릴 때부터 훈련받은 과제에서는 성과가 좋지 않을 수 있지만, 그들이 결코 어리석지 않다는 의미이다. 본문은 이어서 원주민들이 정글에서의 미묘한 변화를 감지하고, 포식자의 흔적을 따라가며, 어떤 곤충을 피해야 하는지 알고, 음식을 찾고, 쉽게 거처를 짓고 해체할 수 있는 능력을 가지고 있다고 설명한다. 이는 원주민들이 자신들의 환경에 맞는 지능과 적응력을 갖추고 있음을 보여준다.

annotations.html: 해설: 이 구절은 기업가들이 자신이 만든 제품에 대한 강한 소유감으로 인해 제품의 실제 가치를 객관적으로 평가하지 못하는 현상을 설명한다. 본문에서는 기업가들이 자신이 깊이 관심을 갖고 만든 제품에 대해 강한 소유의식을 느끼고, 이로 인해 가치 인식이 왜곡되어 결국 제품 가격을 너무 높게 책정하게 된다고 설명하고 있다. 이는 기업가들이 제품에 대한 감정적 투자로 인해 제품의 가치를 과대평가한다는 의미이다.

annotations.html: 해설: 밑줄 친 부분은 인간의 번식 전략을 설명하는 것으로, 천천히 성숙하고, 큰 신체를 발달시키며, 적은 수의 자녀를 낳지만 그들을 잘 양육하는 데 많은 시간과 에너지를 투자한다는 의미이다. 본문에서는 이러한 전략이 성공적인 이유가 적은 수의 자녀를 낳더라도 더 높은 비율의 자녀가 생존하여 번식할 수 있기 때문이라고 설명한다. 이는 쥐와 같이 많은 자녀를 빠르게 낳지만 대부분이 어릴 때 죽는 전략과 대조된다. 따라서 인간의 번식 전략은 적은 수의 자녀에게 많은 투자를 함으로써 그들의 생존 가능성을 높이는 것이다.

annotations.html: 해설: 이 글은 생태학적 오류(ecological fallacy)에 대해 설명하고 있다. 두 현상이 함께 발생한다고 해서 그 사이에 인과관계가 있다고 주장하는 것은 잘못된 추론이라고 말한다. 1950년대 이민자가 많은 지역에서 범죄율이 높았다는 사실로 이민자가 범죄의 원인이라고 주장한 것은 오류이며, 실제로는 이민자들이 이미 범죄율이 높은 지역에 살 수밖에 없었던 것이라고 설명한다.

annotations.html: 해설: 이 글은 서로 다른 환경이 사람들의 주의력 집중 대상에 영향을 미친다는 내용이다. 뉴기니 원주민들은 서구인들이 잘하는 과제에서는 성과가 좋지 않지만, 정글에서의 미묘한 변화를 감지하고 먹이를 찾는 등의 능력이 뛰어나다. 반면 다이아몬드는 그런 환경에 익숙하지 않아 그러한 것들에 주의를 기울이는 능력이 없다. 이는 사람들이 자신의 환경에 맞게 주의를 기울이는 대상이 달라진다는 것을 보여준다.

annotations.html: 해설: 이 글은 신제품 출시 시 적절한 가격 전략에 대해 설명하고 있다. 많은 기업가들이 초기에 제품 가격을 높게 책정하는 실수를 범하지만, 실제로는 시장 채택을 빠르게 확보하기 위해 초기 가격과 이익을 희생할 준비가 되어 있어야 하며, 판매량이 충분히 확보된 후에 가격을 인상하여 이익을 극대화할 수 있다고 말한다. 따라서 신제품 출시 시 적절한 가격 전략은 시장 점유율 확보 후 가격 인상으로 이어져야 한다는 것이 글의 요지이다.

annotations.html: 해설: 이 글은 인간을 포함한 일부 종(유인원, 코끼리)이 다른 종(쥐)과 달리 더 많은 에너지를 투자하여 천천히 번식하는 전략을 취한다고 설명한다. 이들은 천천히 성숙하고, 큰 신체를 가지며, 적은 수의 자손을 낳지만 그들을 키우는 데 많은 시간과 에너지를 쏟는다. 이러한 전략은 비록 적은 수의 자손을 낳지만 더 높은 비율의 자손이 생존하여 번식에 성공하기 때문에 효과적이라는 내용이다.

annotations.html: 해설: 이 글에 따르면 과학자들은 중요한 발견이나 가설 증명을 했을 때 그 정보를 혼자 간직하지 않고 출판하여 공유한다. 이는 다른 과학자들이 그 데이터를 검토하고 새로운 가설을 세우며 실험을 수행할 수 있게 한다. 글의 핵심은 정보가 널리 공유될 때 사회 전체가 더 많은 지식을 얻게 된다는 것이며, 모든 과학자는 다른 과학자들의 연구에 의존한다는 점을 강조한다.

annotations.html: 해설: 이 글은 Edward O. Wilson의 출생부터 사망까지 생애와 학문적 여정을 시간 순서대로 다루고 있다. 어린 시절 사고로 인한 시력 저하가 개미 연구로 이어진 계기, 하버드 대학교에서의 교수직, 그리고 '현대의 다윈'이라 불릴 만큼 진화생물학에 기여한 업적을 포괄적으로 서술하고 있다. 다른 선택지들은 본문에서 언급된 일부 내용에만 초점을 맞추고 있어 글 전체의 주제를 대표하지 못한다.

annotations.html: 해설: 이 글은 Edward O. Wilson의 생애에 관한 전기적 내용을 다루고 있다. 그의 출생부터 어린 시절 자연에 대한 관심, 7세 때 겪은 낚시 사고로 인한 시력 손상이 개미 연구로 이어진 계기, 학업 과정, Harvard 대학 교수 임용, Crafoord 상 수상, 그리고 92세에 사망한 사실까지 Wilson의 생애 전반을 시간 순으로 서술하고 있다.
annotations.text: 해설: 이 글은 Edward O. Wilson의 생애에 관한 전기적 내용을 다루고 있다. 그의 출생부터 어린 시절 자연에 대한 관심, 7세 때 겪은 낚시 사고로 인한 시력 손상이 개미 연구로 이어진 계기, 학업 과정, Harvard 대학 교수 임용, Crafoord 상 수상, 그리고 92세에 사망한 사실까지 Wilson의 생애 전반을 시간 순으로 서술하고 있다.

annotations.html: 해설: 이 글은 전문가의 특성에 대해 설명하며, 전문가란 단순히 뛰어난 사고력이나 지능을 가진 사람이 아니라 특정 분야에서 깊고 풍부하게 연결된 지식을 가진 사람임을 강조한다. 글에서는 "Experts are not just good thinkers or people who are exceptionally smart"라고 명시하며, 전문가의 지식은 "organized into coherent frameworks"되어 있고 사실들 간의 상호관계를 이해하며 핵심 아이디어를 구별할 수 있다고 설명한다. 이러한 조직화된 이해가 학습의 유연성과 다양한 맥락에서의 적용을 가능하게 한다는 내용으로, 전문가의 본질적 특성이 지능이나 단순 사실 암기를 넘어선다는 점을 다루고 있다.

annotations.html: 해설: 이 글은 생태학적 오류(ecological fallacy)라는 개념을 중심으로 설명하고 있다. 생태학적 오류는 두 현상이 단순히 함께 발생한다는 이유만으로 인과관계가 있다고 주장하는 논리적 오류이다. 글에서는 1950년대 이민자가 많은 지역에서 범죄율이 높았던 사례를 들어 이민자들이 범죄의 원인이라고 잘못 해석한 경우를 설명하고 있다. 실제로는 이민자들이 이미 범죄율이 높은 지역에 살 수밖에 없었던 상황이었으며, 이민자들 자신은 범죄를 거의 저지르지 않았다는 분석을 통해 단순한 공존(co-occurrence)을 인과관계로 잘못 해석하는 생태학적 오류의 본질을 명확히 보여주고 있다.
annotations.text: 해설: 이 글은 생태학적 오류(ecological fallacy)라는 개념을 중심으로 설명하고 있다. 생태학적 오류는 두 현상이 단순히 함께 발생한다는 이유만으로 인과관계가 있다고 주장하는 논리적 오류이다. 글에서는 1950년대 이민자가 많은 지역에서 범죄율이 높았던 사례를 들어 이민자들이 범죄의 원인이라고 잘못 해석한 경우를 설명하고 있다. 실제로는 이민자들이 이미 범죄율이 높은 지역에 살 수밖에 없었던 상황이었으며, 이민자들 자신은 범죄를 거의 저지르지 않았다는 분석을 통해 단순한 공존(co-occurrence)을 인과관계로 잘못 해석하는 생태학적 오류의 본질을 명확히 보여주고 있다.

annotations.html: 해설: 이 글은 우리가 일상생활에서 이전 경험을 바탕으로 주의를 기울일 곳을 예측하며, 서로 다른 환경이 다른 기대를 만든다고 설명한다. 저자는 Jared Diamond의 예시를 통해 뉴기니 원주민들이 서구인들이 어릴 때부터 훈련받은 과제에는 약하지만, 정글에서의 미묘한 변화를 감지하고 포식자의 흔적을 따라가는 등 그들의 환경에 맞는 기술에는 뛰어나다는 점을 보여준다. 반면 Diamond는 그런 환경에서 시간을 보낸 적이 없어 그런 것들에 주의를 기울이는 능력이 없다고 언급한다. 따라서 환경 적응과 경험에 따라 형성되는 주의력에 관한 내용을 담은 제목이 가장 적절하다.

annotations.html: 해설: 이 글은 기업가들이 새 제품이나 서비스를 출시할 때 초기에 가격을 너무 높게 책정하는 실수를 범한다고 지적한다. 글의 핵심 메시지는 "새 제품이나 서비스를 출시할 때 우선순위는 가능한 빨리 충분한 시장 채택을 얻는 것이어야 하며, 이 목표를 달성하기 위해 초기 가격과 이익을 희생할 준비가 되어 있어야 한다"는 것이다. 또한 "강력한 판매량이 확보되면 이익을 극대화하기 위해 가격을 인상할 수 있다"고 언급하고 있어, 먼저 낮은 가격으로 시장을 확보한 후 나중에 이익을 추구하는 전략을 제시하고 있다.

annotations.html: 해설: 이 글은 인간을 포함한 일부 종들이 적은 수의 자손을 천천히 번식시키는 전략을 택한 반면, 쥐와 같은 종들은 빠르게 많은 자손을 생산하는 대조적인 번식 전략에 대해 설 명하고 있다. 글에서 "humans are one of a relatively small number of species that evolved a very different strategy of investing more energy to reproduce more slowly"라고 언급하며, 이러한 전략이 성공하는 이유는 "a larger percentage of their offspring survive to then reproduce"라는 점을 강조한 다. 따라서 품질(생존율)과 수량(자손의 수) 간의 서로 다른 번식 전략을 대비하는 제목이 글의 핵심 내용을 가장 잘 나타낸다.

annotations.html: 해설: 이 글은 과학자들이 새로운 발견이나 가설 증명을 했을 때 그 정보를 자신만 간직하는 것이 아니라 출판하고 데이터를 공개함으로써 다른 과학자들이 검토하고 새로운 가설을 세우는 데 활용할 수 있게 한다는 내용을 다루고 있다. 글에서는 "society as a whole will end up knowing more if information is spread as widely as possible"라고 언급하며 정보 공유의 중요성을 강조하고, "every scientist depends on the work of other scientists"라고 결론짓고 있어 과학적 발전에 정보 공유가 필수적이라는 내용을 담은 제목이 가장 적절하다.

annotations.html: 해설: 이 글은 Edward O. Wilson의 생애에 관한 내용으로, 어린 시절 낚시 사고로 시력이 부분적으로 손상되어 먼 거리에서 큰 동물들을 관찰할 수 없게 되었다고 설명한다. 그 결과 Wilson은 가까이에서 관찰할 수 있는 작은 생물, 특히 개미 연구에 집중하게 되었다. 따라서 빈칸에는 시력 손상으로 인해 그가 작은 생물에 집중하게 되었다는 내용이 들어가는 것이 문맥상 가장 적절하다.

annotations.html: 해설: 이 글은 전문가들의 지식 구조에 관한 내용으로, 전문가들은 단순히 많은 사실을 아는 것이 아니라 지식을 체계적으로 조직화한다고 설명한다. 빈칸 이후에 전문가가 사실들 간의 상호관계를 이해하고 핵심 아이디어를 구별할 수 있다고 언급하는 것으로 보아, 지식이 일관된 체계로 조직화되어 있음을 강조한다. 또한 마지막 문장에서 이러한 조직화된 이해가 학습의 유연성과 다양한 맥락에서의 적용을 가능하게 한다고 설명하므로, 지식이 '체계적으로 정보를 구조화하는 일관된 프레임워크'로 조직화된다는 답이 가장 적절하다.

annotations.html: 이 글은 생태학적 오류(ecological fallacy)에 대해 설명하고 있으며, 이는 두 현상이 단순히 함께 발생한다는 이유만으로 인과관계가 있다고 주장하는 오류를 의미한다. 예시에서는 1950년대에 이민자가 많은 지역에서 범죄율이 높았다는 공존 현상(co-occurrence)을 근거로 이민자가 범죄의 원인이라고 잘못 추론한 사례를 보여준다. 그러나 실제로는 이민자들이 이미 범죄율이 높은 지역에 살 수밖에 없었던 상황적 요인이 있었음을 설명하고 있다. 따라서 생태학적 오류의 핵심은 '단순히 함께 발생한다는 이유만으로' 인과관계를 주장하는 것이다.

annotations.html: 이 글은 서로 다른 환경이 사람들의 주의력과 능력에 미치는 영향을 설명하고 있다. 뉴기니 원주민들이 서구인들이 잘하는 일에는 약하지만, 정글에서 생존하는 데 필요한 다양한 기술들을 가지고 있다는 내용을 나열하고 있다. 빈칸은 원주민들이 가진 여러 생존 기술 중 하나로, 원문에서 언급된 '쉽게 거처를 짓고 철거할 수 있다'는 내용이 들어가는 것이 문맥상 자연스럽다.

annotations.html: 해설: 이 글은 많은 기업가들이 자신의 제품에 대한 강한 소유감으로 인해 가격을 너무 높게 책정하는 실수를 범한다고 설명한다. 글의 후반부에서는 새 제품이나 서비스를 출시할 때 초기 가격과 이익을 희생해서라도 우선시해야 할 것이 무엇인지 언급하고 있으며, 이후 판매량이 강해지면 가격을 올려 이익을 극대화할 수 있다고 말한다. 따라서 빈칸에는 '충분한 시장 채택을 얻는 것'이 가장 적절하며, 이는 글의 전체 맥락과 논리적으로 일치한다.

annotations.html: 해설: 지문은 생태학적 오류(ecological fallacy)를 설명하고 있으며, 이는 두 사건이 단순히 함께 발생한다는 이유만으로 인과관계가 있다고 잘못 가정하는 것을 말함. 이민자와 범죄율의 예시에서 보듯이, 두 현상의 공존(coexistence) 만으로 인과적(causal) 관계를 추론하는 오류를 범하게 됨. 지문에서 "claims that there is a causal relationship between two things merely because they occur together"라는 부분이 이를 직접적으로 뒷받침함.

(1) 해설: 텍스트에 따르면 Wilson은 1929 년에 태어났으며, 이는 1920년대에 해당한다. "Edward O. Wilson was born in Birmingham, Alabama, in 1929."라고 명시되어 있다.
(2) 해설: 텍스트에 따르면 Wilson은 7살 때 낚시 사고로 부분적으로 시력을 잃었고, 이로 인해 개미 연구에 관심을 갖게 되었다. "At age seven, he was partially blinded in a fishing accident; his reduced sight led Wilson to the study of ants."라고 명시되어 있다.
(3) 해설: Wilson은 1929년에 태어났고 1956년에 하버드 대학교 교수가 되었다. 따라서 그는 27세에 교수가 되었으므로 30세 이전에 교수가 된 것이 맞다. "Wilson transferred to Harvard University, where he became a professor in 1956."라고 언급되어 있다.
(4) 해설: 텍스트에 따르면 Wilson은 노벨상을 받지 못했다. "He never received a Nobel Prize - the prize didn't recognize research in the field of evolutionary biology."라고 명시되어 있다.
(5) 해설: Wilson은 앨라배마 출신이지만 매사추세츠에서 사망했다. 텍스트에서 "Wilson... died at the age of 92 in Massachusetts."라고 언급되어 있다.

(3) 해설: Wilson은 1929년에 태어났고 1956년에 하버드 대학교 교수가 되었다. 따라서 그는 27세에 교수가 되었으므로 30세 이전에 교수가 된 것이 맞다. "Wilson transferred to Harvard University, where he became a professor in 1956."라고 언급되어 있다.
(4) 해설: 텍스트에 따르면 Wilson은 노벨상을 받지 못했다. "He never received a Nobel Prize - the prize didn't recognize research in the field of evolutionary biology."라고 명시되어 있다.
(5) 해설: Wilson은 앨라배마 출신이지만 매사추세츠에서 사망했다. 텍스트에서 "Wilson... died at the age of 92 in Massachusetts."라고 언급되어 있다.

(2) 해설: 텍스트에서 "having expertise in a topic means that knowledge is organized into coherent frameworks"라고 명시하고 있으며, 전문가들은 단순히 "a bunch of facts"를 아는 것이 아니라고 설명한다.
(3) 해설: 텍스트는 "They are not just good thinkers or people who are exceptionally smart"라고 명시하며, 전문가는 단순히 똑똑한 사람이 아니라 특정 영역에 깊은 지식을 가진 사람임을 강조한다.
(4) 해설: 텍스트의 마지막 문장에서 "This kind of deep but organized understanding allows for greater flexibility in learning and facilitates application across multiple contexts"라고 명확히 언급하고 있다.

annotations.html:
(1) 해설: 생태적 오류(ecological fallacy)는 두 가지가 함께 발생한다는 이유만으로 인과관계가 있다고 주장하는 것이다. 텍스트에서 "the ecological fallacy, where an argument claims that there is a causal relationship between two things merely because they occur together"라고 명시되어 있다.
(2) 해설: 텍스트에 따르면, 이민자들은 범죄의 아주 일부만 저질렀다. "Immigrants themselves committed very few of the crimes"라고 명확히 언급되어 있다.
(3) 해설: 텍스트의 첫 문장에서 "It is natural for people to observe happenings and then seek explanations for why those happenings occurred"라고 언급하고 있다.
(4) 해설: 이민자들은 범죄율이 높은 지역에 살 수밖에 없었던 것이지 선택한 것이 아니다. 텍스트에서 "immigrants were forced to live in neighborhoods where crime rates were already high; they could not afford more expensive housing in safer neighborhoods"라고 설명하고 있다.
(5) 해설: 텍스트의 마지막 문장에서 "Unless you analyze the claim carefully, you would misinterpret the relationship and thereby construct a faulty belief"라고 언급하고 있어, 데이터를 신중히 분석하는 것이 잘못된 믿음을 형성하지 않기 위해 중요하다는 것을 알 수 있다.

annotations.html:
(1) 해설: 텍스트에서는 Diamond의 책 "Guns, Germs, and Steel"이 정글 생존 기술에 관한 것이라고 명시하지 않았다. 단지 그가 이 책에서 뉴기니 정글에서의 모험을 통해 환경과 기대치의 차이를 설명했다고만 언급하고 있다.
(2) 해설: 텍스트에서 "He relates that these natives tend to perform poorly at tasks Westerners have been trained to do since childhood"라고 명확히 언급하고 있다.
(3) 해설: 텍스트의 첫 문장에서 "In everyday life, we use previous experience to predict where we should pay attention. Different environments create different expectations."라고 명시하고 있으며, 뉴기니 원주민과 Diamond의 예를 통해 이를 설명하고 있다.
(4) 해설: 텍스트에 따르면, "Diamond, who had never spent time in such places, has no ability to pay attention to these things"라고 명시되어 있어 그가 정글 환경의 미묘한 변화를 감지하는 데 능숙하지 않았음을 보여준다.
(5) 해설: 텍스트에서 뉴기니 원주민들이 "can build and tear down shelters with ease"라고 명확히 언급하고 있다.

annotations.html:
(1) 해설: 텍스트의 첫 문장에서 "Most entrepreneurs put in tremendous amounts of time and effort in creating and launching new products and services and then make the mistake of overpricing them."라고 명시하고 있어, 대부분의 기업가들이 제품을 처음 출시할 때 과대 가격을 책정한다고 설명한다
(2) 해설: 텍스트에서 "this powerful sense of ownership distorts their perception of value which causes them to overprice their products"라고 언급하고 있어, 소유감이 기업가들의 가치 인식을 왜곡시킨다고 설명한다.
(3) 해설: 텍스트에 따르면, "While many of them are quick to realize that their initial prices are too high, not all these people are happy or willing to drop their prices to make their products more attractive."라고 언급하고 있어, 모든 기업가가 가격을 낮추려고 하는 것은 아니다.
(4) 해설: 텍스트에서 "And this can be a very costly mistake that may lead to the failure of their new business."라고 명시하고 있어, 과대 가격 책정이 새로운 사업의 실패로 이어질 수 있다고 설명한다.
(5) 해설: 텍스트 마지막 문장에서 "Once you have strong sales volumes, you can increase your prices to maximize your profits."라고 언급하고 있어, 강한 판매량을 달성한 후에 가격을 인상할 수 있다고 제안한다.

annotations.html:
(1) 해설: 인간, 유인원, 코끼리는 양보다 질에 초점을 맞춘 번식 전략을 진화시켰다. 텍스트에 따르면, "humans are one of a relatively small number of species that evolved a very different strategy of investing more energy to reproduce more slowly" 그리고 "have few babies but devote much time and energy to raising them well"이라고 명시되어 있다.
(2) 해설: 집쥐는 5주령에 어미가 될 수 있다. 텍스트에 서 "A house mouse can become a mother when she is just five weeks old"라고 명확히 언급되어 있다.
(3) 해설: 침팬지나 코끼리 어미는 한 번에 한 마리의 새끼만 낳는다. 텍스트에 따르면, "she gives birth to only one infant every five or six years"라고 명시되 어 있다.
(4) 해설: 코끼리와 유인원의 자손 생존율이 쥐보다 높다. 텍스트에서 "while apes and elephants produce fewer babies than mice, a larger percentage of their offspring survive to then reproduce"라고 언급되어 있고, 쥐는 "the vast majority of her pups die young"인 반면 코끼리와 침팬지는 "About half of these offspring make it to becoming parents"라고 명시되어 있다.
(5) 해설: 코끼리나 침팬지의 번식 기간은 성적 성숙 이후 약 30년 정도이다. 텍스트에서 "she gives birth to only one infant every five or six years over the next thirty or so years"라고 언급되어 있다.

annotations.html:
(1) 해설: 과학자들은 일반적으로 발견을 자신만의 것으로 유지하지 않는다. 텍스트에서 "they do not, in general, keep that information to themselves"라고 명시되어 있다.
(2) 해설: 과학적 결과를 발표하면 다른 과학자들이 그 데이터를 재검토하고 결론을 반박할 수 있다. 텍스트에 따르면, "This makes it possible for other scientists to reconsider their data and possibly refute their conclusions."라고 언급되어 있다.
(3) 해설: 과학적 데이터 공유의 주요 목적은 다른 과학자들이 새로운 가설을 구축하고 새로운 실험을 수행할 수 있게 하는 것이다. 텍스트에서는 "More important, though, it makes it possible for other scientists to use that data to construct new hypotheses and perform new experiments."라고 설명하고 있다.
(4) 해설: 정보가 널리 퍼질수록 사회 전체가 더 많이 알게 된다는 가정이 있다. 텍스트에서 "The assumption is that society as a whole will end up knowing more if information is spread as widely as possible"라고 언급되어 있다.
(5) 해설: 모든 과학자는 다른 과학자들의 작업에 의존한다. 텍스트의 마지막 문장에서 "In a strict sense, every scientist depends on the work of other scientists."라고 명확히 언급하고 있다.

annotations.html: ​해설: 본문에서는 "Immigrants themselves committed very few of the crimes"라고 명시하여 이민자들이 범죄의 대부분을 저지른 것이 아니라 오히려 매우 적은 범죄만 저질렀다고 설명하고 있다. 따라서 이민자들이 대부분의 범죄에 책임이 있다는 내용은 본문과 일치하지 않는다. 나머지 보기들은 모두 본문 내용과 일치한다. 생태학적 오류는 단순히 공존한다는 이유로 인과관계를 주장하는 것이며, 1950년대에 일부 사람들이 이민자들을 범죄율의 원인으로 잘못 비난했고, 이민자들은 안전한 지역의 주택을 감당할 수 없어 범죄율이 높은 지역에 살았으며, 관계를 신중하게 분석하지 않으면 잘못된 믿음을 형성할 수 있다는 내용은 모두 본문에서 언급된 사실과 일치한다.

annotations.html: 해설: 본문에서는 기업가들이 자신의 제품에 대해 깊이 관심을 갖고 있으며, 이러한 강한 소유감이 그들의 가치 인식을 왜곡하여 제품 가격을 너무 높게 책정하게 만든다고 언급하고 있다. 나머지 보기들은 본문 내용과 일치하지 않는다. 기업가들은 제품을 낮게 책정하는 것이 아니라 높게 책정하는 경향이 있고, 많은 기업가들이 가격이 너무 높다는 것을 깨닫지만 모두가 기꺼이 가격을 낮추려 하지는 않는다. 또한 신제품 출시 시 최우선 과제는 이윤 극대화가 아니라 시장 채택을 가능한 빨리 확보하는 것이며, 사업 실패는 제품에 대한 관심 부족이 아니라 과도한 가격 책정 때문이라고 설명하고 있다.

annotations.html: 해설: 본문의 마지막 문장에서 침팬지나 코끼리의 자손 중 약 절반이 부모가 되는 단계까지 생존한다고 명시하고 있다. 다른 보기들은 본문 내용과 일치하지 않는다. 인간, 유인원, 코끼리는 더 천천히 번식하는 전략을 발전시켰고, 집쥐는 약 12개월 동안 살며 2개월마다 새끼를 낳으며, 인간의 번식 전략은 소수 종의 전략이며, 침팬지와 코끼리는 최소 12살이 되어야 번식을 시작한다.
